abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Fourth Drainage
            Project for Pakistan was satisfactory. The project achieved
            most of its objectives, its impact on institutional
            development has been substantial, sustainability is
            uncertain at this time, and both the Bank and Borrower
            performed satisfactorily. Several lessons can be learned
            from this project. For the Bank, previous implementation
            experience in the country must be used when setting progress
            rates for projects. Second, bilateral co-financing can
            influence project performance if it affects the supply of
            appropriate equipment. Third, supervision staffing should
            take into account the problems being experienced by the
            project. Lastly, arrangements for O&M need to be
            fostered by establishing a budget for the O&M
            organization well before the expenditure will commence. For
            the Borrower, pre-qualification of bidders needs careful
            thought if a good short list is to be established. Second,
            contracts extending for more than one year should include
            price escalation clauses, as required in the Bank's
            guidelines. Lastly, an offer of grant aid tied to purchase
            of supplies or equipment must be carefully considered to
            ensure that adequate after-scale service is provided within
            the country.
